Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] Gartner note on WOA (Web-Oriented Architecture) just published
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=343278744; y=4kugaNNFeFqGz8dsMTanrGqaeuaONmp1xv61CSyr6K9JpZI
X-Yahoo-Profile: sallamar

AFAIU, this is about "shared understanding" of media types across  
applications. Does it make the interface "application neutral"? Not  
necessarily. The application that is processing a representation needs  
to know what the representation is about - i.e. it needs to know the  
specifics. Even in the case of Atom, the application needs to know  
about the content's media type, and any extensions used.

It may however, allow some domain-specific layered software do some  
useful stuff without understanding all the pieces of the  
representation. This is very similar to how SOAP intermediaries may be  
able to process some SOAP headers. For instance, someone vendor using  
XML representations with some common elements/attributes, so that  
their gateway-level software can do some generic things.

> SOAP is indeed application neutral. Perhaps even more application  
> neutral than HTTP itself, since SOAP is little more than a framework  
> for an XML envelope with completely open ended XML header  
> processing. It is extremely application neutral. The problem is,  
> interface designers take the incredibly generic SOAP format and put  
> an incredibly application specific XML payload inside it. That's  
> like stepping of a neutrality cliff -- from extremely generic to  
> extremely specific in one step.

How else should they do it? If applications need to do "real" stuff,  
they need to exchange "specifics". Why is this like stepping off a  
cliff?

> Of course the same can happen (and does happen) with Atom entities  
> or even with representations returned by HTTP itself. But it seems  
> to us that interface designers in the REST "camp" seem to better  
> understand the importance of reusing existing representations for  
> new applications, not custom designing

It depends. Even the GData examples you cited do indeed have very  
specific representations wrapped inside a generic media types. That  
does not make those architecture any more generic than, say, an  
application using "foo/bar" media type.

> representations for each new application. An example of this is the  
> RESTafarian insistence that HTTP is NOT a transport protocol, but  
> rather an "application protocol", albeit a VERY application neutral  
> one. What we haven't seen yet, even from the REST "camp" is much in  
> the way of fairly generic ATOM entities to go

I am really confused by this. By adding a "fifth constraint" I thought  
this report is agreeing with the other four constraints, and hence  
that HTTP is an application protocol. Not so? How does WOA treat HTTP?  
As an application protocol or as a transport protocol?

>  inside the ATOM "envelope". Many REST examples using ATOM step off  
> the same cliff.

Could you give an example please? How would you build an app that does  
not fall of this cliff.

Sincerely,
Subbu
